LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of Uzbekistan

Project Description  The Project follows a sector lending approach and supports the 
Government’s  objectives  of  decentralization,  poverty  reduction, 
and  human  development  by  providing  (i)  improved  rural  water 
supply  and  sanitation  (WSS)  infrastructure  services,  and 
(ii) training  programs  to  strengthen  institutional  capacity.  The 
Project consists of two parts: Part A: physical infrastructure and 
Part B: institutional development. Part A consists of 12 subprojects, 
each covering a cluster of villages. The subprojects will include 
developing and rehabilitating piped water supply systems, public 
and school latrines, and wastewater facilities. Part B includes a 
capacity-building  program,  a  hygiene  and  sanitation  education 
program, and consulting services for project management support. 
The Project will cover two oblasts (provinces), Kashkadarya and 
Navoi, and will provide basic WSS infrastructure services to about 
250,000 people, about 30% of whom are living below the poverty 
line. 
   
Rationale  Inadequate  delivery  of  rural  WSS  services  caused  by  aging 
infrastructure,  institutional  constraints,  and  fiscal  difficulties  is 
inhibiting  communities’  access  to  basic  WSS  infrastructure 
services.  Existing  facilities  are  often  poorly  designed  and 
insufficiently maintained, and do not adequately provide urgently 
needed basic services. In line with the Government’s policy to use 
a decentralized community management approach, the Project will 
enhance coverage of basic WSS facilities; contribute to improving 
living and health conditions, in particular for the poor; and improve 
the institutional, organizational, and managerial capabilities of the 
oblasts.  The  sector  lending  modality  is  considered  appropriate 
because (i) the Government’s sector policies, strategies, and the 
10-year investment plan for the sector are satisfactory to the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB),  and  (ii)  the  Uzbekistan  Communal 
Services Agency (UCSA) has gained substantial experience and 
capacity  through  implementing  the  World  Bank  water  supply 
project and an ongoing ADB water supply project.

iv 
Impact and Outcome  The impact of the Project is to improve living conditions and public 
health  in  rural  areas  of  Kashkadarya  and  Navoi  oblasts.  The 
outcome  of  the  Project  is  improved  access  to  WSS  in  project 
areas. The Project will assist the Government in (i) implementing 
institutional  reform  for  WSS  infrastructure  services;  and  (ii) 
providing and upgrading reliable and financially sustainable WSS 
services  that  will  improve  public  health,  promote  economic 
development, and reduce rural poverty.

foreign exchange costs of $5.6 million and local currency costs

Implementation  A  central  project  management  unit  will  be  established  within 
Arrangements  UCSA. Project implementation will be carried out by the oblast

Navoi oblasts. A project steering committee will be established to

vv 
Procurement  The procurement of civil works, goods, and services to be financed 
by the ADB loan will be undertaken in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines  for  Procurement.  International  competitive  bidding 
procedures will be applied for supply contracts estimated to cost at 
least  $1  million  equivalent.  Supply  contracts  worth  less  than 
$1 million equivalent will follow international shopping procedures, 
except for supply contracts with a value of less than $100,000 
equivalent,  which  may  be  procured  by  direct  purchase.  Local 
competitive  bidding  procedures  will  be  applied  for  civil  works 
contracts that are valued at less than $2 million.  
   
Consulting Services  The Project will require 680 person-months of consulting services 
(50  person-months  of  international  and  630  person-months  of 
domestic)  for  (i)  review  of  detailed  design,  (ii)  construction 
supervision,  (iii)  finance  and  accounting,  (iv)  community 
development, and (v) project management. The consultants will be 
engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants using quality and cost based selection (QCBS) and 
other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of 
domestic consultants. 
   
Project Benefits and  The Project is expected to benefit 170 villages with populations 
Beneficiaries  ranging from 300 to 8,000. Overall, about 250,000 people, about 
30% of whom are living below the poverty line, will benefit directly 
from the Project through provision of potable quality piped water 
supply  facilities;  improved  wastewater  drainage  facilities;  and 
public, school, and private latrines. The Project will improve health 
conditions  by  reducing  waterborne  diseases.  Related  benefits 
include time and cost savings from purchasing, fetching, treating, 
and storing water; improved public and family hygiene and health; 
reduced  medical  outlays;  and  increased  productivity  days.  The 
core subprojects’ economic internal rate of return is 23% to 36%. 
Support for decentralized community management and capacity 
building will enhance the efficiency and sustainability of rural WSS 
services in Uzbekistan. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  Three possible risks have been identified. First, the possibility of 
delays  in  project  implementation  caused  by  weak  institutional 
capability to implement, operate, and maintain the water supply 
systems has been addressed through clear delineation of agency 
responsibilities  and  inclusion  of  coordination  mechanisms. 
Considerable preparatory work has been undertaken in potential 
subproject  communities  regarding  the  current  status  of  water 
supply facilities, and an initial assessment of required development 
has  been  carried  out.  Substantial  support  will  be  provided  for 
capacity  building  through  training  programs  and  consulting 
services.

vi 
  Second, potential for delays in project implementation caused by 
lack of local counterpart funds has been addressed by the active 
participation of local administration which meets some construction 
supervision  and  all  land  requirements.  Measures  to  reduce 
possible delays have been discussed with the Government.   
 
Third, limited financial capability to meet the incremental operation 
and maintenance (O&M) of the expanded water supply systems 
has  been  managed  by  including  the  institutional  development 
program, which should strengthen the capacity to undertake O&M 
of the expanded water supply systems. The Project will be closely 
monitored, with two reviews per year throughout implementation.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
   
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Kashkadarya and Navoi Rural Water Supply and Sanitation 
Sector Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  The  Government’s  development  objectives  are  to  promote  economic  growth,  reduce 
poverty, and provide balanced regional development—including improved water supply and 
sanitation (WSS) services. The country’s WSS facilities are often poorly designed, inadequately 
maintained, and in a poor state of repair. Rural water supply has particularly suffered from 
budget cuts since independence. Formerly, an estimated 70% of all rural villages had piped 
potable water supply. Lack of funding for operation and maintenance (O&M) is the main reason 
that many water supply systems are constantly out of service. In spite of the Government’s 
efforts to reestablish the level of water supply service, the percentage of villages with piped 
water supply is currently relatively low. Rural areas in the oblasts of Kashkadarya and Navoi are 
particularly poorly served with piped water supply. Recent surveys show that only about 30% of 
villages in Kashkadarya and Navoi oblasts have access to piped water supply. Annual funding 
to the sector is generally limited to routine maintenance and repairs. The level of tariffs—
targeted to cover O&M costs—is low, collection management is poor, and insufficient money is 
raised to support efficient operation.  
 
3.  Lack of adequate WSS services also has a large negative impact on community health, 
especially the poor. In rural areas, people often have to walk long distances only to obtain 
contaminated water from untreated sources. There are few wastewater collection systems in 
rural areas and waste disposal infrastructure is below acceptable standards. Insufficient and 
polluted drinking water supplies, combined with poor sanitation and hygiene practices, are 
directly  linked  to  the  high  incidence  of  waterborne  diseases.  As  a  consequence  of  major 
government reforms in the health sector since 1998, expected life expectancy at birth has 
increased and the infant mortality rate has decreased substantially. Nevertheless, maternal, 
child, and infant mortality remain high. Water-related diseases such as hepatitis A, typhoid 
fever, skin allergies, and kidney disease are widespread, particularly in rural areas. In the 
Kashkadarya and Navoi oblasts, indicators of infectious morbidity remain significantly high.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
4.  Sector Policies. Since the promulgation of the Law on Water and Water Use, 1993, the 
Government  has  gradually  extended  and  strengthened  the  legislative  framework  covering 
Uzbekistan’s needs in the WSS sector, particularly in rural areas. Needs include improvement of 
physical and institutional structures, promotion of sector decentralization, conservation of water 
resources, and implementation of sound tariff and cost-recovery policies. Uzbekistan’s WSS 
policy is now underpinned by three legal instruments: (i) the national 10-year water supply 
development plan approved by the Cabinet of Ministers in 1999, (ii) the Resolution of the 
Cabinet  of  Ministers  approved  in  2003  (RCM)  No.  405,  and  (iii)  the  latest  annual  public 
investment program approved by the Cabinet of Ministers. 
 
5.  The key objectives of the WSS policy are to: (i) improve water sector services through a 
national water supply development plan; (ii) attain financial sustainability through an effective

2 
tariff system and cost recovery; (iii) plan adequate investments with domestic and external 
funding; (iv) achieve further decentralization of WSS services; (v) encourage private sector 
participation and public-private partnerships in the sector; (vi) implement hygiene and sanitation 
education programs in schools; (vii) achieve improved livelihood conditions, particularly for the 
benefit  of  women  in  rural  areas;  (viii)  ensure  environmental  compliance  by  encouraging 
conservative development of water resources, economic use of water, consistent water quality 
control, and sound management of wastewater; and (ix) improve further operational strategies 
by strengthening the sector’s institutional setup and interagency collaboration, and by promoting 
adequate capacity building. A summary of Uzbekistan’s WSS policy is in Appendix 2 and a full 
description is in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
6.  The Government is targeting the Millennium Development Goal to ensure environmental 
sustainability  and  aims  to  halve  the  number  of  people without  sustainable  access  to  safe 
drinking water by 2010. Currently, access to safe drinking water is estimated at 30% in rural 
areas and 70% in urban areas. The overall goal of the Government's WSS sector plan is to 
improve the health and living conditions of the population by providing better access to safe and 
adequate amounts of water supply, and better sanitation services. To achieve this goal, the 
following  objectives  must  be  met:  (i)  invest  in  the  development  of  WSS  infrastructure, 
particularly in rural areas; (ii) undertake institutional reforms necessary for effective and efficient 
development and operation of WSS; (iii) implement a system of equitable and transparent tariff 
setting based on cost recovery objectives, taking into account the needs of the poor; (v) develop 
effective implementation mechanisms, including cost recovery for WSS in market conditions; 
and (vi) involve the private sector in WSS management.  
 
7.  Sector Investment Plan. The national water supply development plan is based on three 
basic documents: (i) the 10-year water supply development plan approved by the Government 
in 1999; (ii) the 2003 law providing additional measures to improve of the supply of water and 
natural gas to rural settlements (RCM No. 405); and (iii) the latest annual investment program 
approved by the Cabinet of Ministers. Under its WSS policy, the Government committed to a  
10-year  program  (2000–2010)  aimed  at  improving  the  supply  of  water  to  urban  and  rural 
communities, many of which currently have inadequate or no water supply. This program, 
developed in 1999 and modified in 2003, envisages the construction of water supply systems 
and the improvement of the level of service of drinking water supply to benefit up to 85% of 
Uzbekistan’s rural population.  
 
8.  In  implementing  the  water  supply  development  plan,  the  Government  has  placed 
particular emphasis on the: (i) development of long-distance, interregional transmission mains, 
carrying water from its source to urban and rural settlements where no fresh water is available; 
(ii) coverage of a significant part of the urban and rural population with water supply by 2010, 
and full coverage of the rural population by 2020; and (iii) rehabilitation of water supply networks 
in urban centers. Under the plan, the Government estimated the total cost of reconstruction of 
the urban water supply sector at $896 million until 2005, with an additional $1,527 million 
required from 2006 to 2010. The cost of rehabilitation of the rural water supply sector was 
estimated  at  $930  million  (until  2005)  and  $1,706  million  (2006–2010).  To  date,  about 
$433 million has been committed by the Government for rehabilitation and extension of the 
long-distance water transmission mains. Concerning the long-term investment plan, the 2005 
investment  plan  includes  the  estimated  costs  of  planned  post-2010  investments,  covering 
12 WSS projects totaling $363.3 million. An estimated additional $700 million would be needed 
to cover the remaining rural areas with water supply by 2020. In pursuing the objectives of 
implementing the plan, the Government has undertaken steps aimed at diversifying investments 
and sources of funding. This includes attracting international funding, which is expected to be

3 
provided mainly by ADB and the World Bank, as well as bilateral donors. The summary WSS 
sector  investment  plan  is  in  Appendix  3  and  the  detailed  sector  investment  plan  is  in 
Supplementary Appendix B. 
 
9.  Sector Institutions. Several government agencies are involved in the development and 
operations of the WSS sector. The Uzbekistan Communal Services Agency (UCSA) is the main 
agency responsible for WSS sector development and protection of water sources. UCSA covers 
tasks ranging from regulatory to commercial including: (i) provision of regulatory advice and 
support to reforms in the communal services sector, (ii) monitoring the compliance of local 
authorities and commercial entities with sector policies, and (iii) attracting foreign investment in 
the sector. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is responsible for implementation of the Government’s 
health  and  hygiene  policies,  and  monitors  water  quality  through  the  State  Sanitary  and 
Epidemiological Inspectorate which has branches at oblast and rayon (district) levels. The State 
Committee for Geology and Mineral Resources is responsible for controlling the exploitation of 
groundwater sources, and the State Committee for Environmental Protection is responsible for 
ensuring compliance with quality standards in natural water resources. The oblast governments 
are responsible for O&M of rural WSS facilities through oblast and rayon vodokanals (water 
supply and sanitation agencies). 
 
10.  Capacity of the Executing Agency. The Executing Agency (EA) for the Project, the 
UCSA, has the technical, financial, and managerial capability to implement the Project and 
manage  the  newly  constructed  rural  water  supply  systems  in  the  long  term,  ensuring:  (i) 
affordable cost recovery, (ii) sound water tariff policies, and (iii) appropriate management of the 
newly constituted WSS utilities. UCSA will have the authority to delegate responsibilities to the 
oblast level. Kashkadarya and Navoi oblasts have adequate personnel available and will be 
contributing  financially  to  the  Project.  UCSA  has  the  capacity  to  establish  the  institutional 
structures  required  at  the  recipient  level  in  a  timely  and  appropriate  manner,  and  is  also 
equipped to provide the necessary capacity building. UCSA currently satisfies ADB’s minimum 
financial  management  requirements  and  has  the  financial  management  capability  to 
satisfactorily  record  all  transactions  and  balances,  support  the  preparation  of  regular  and 
reliable financial statements and financial monitoring reports, and arrange for annual audits to 
be carried out in a manner acceptable to ADB. The summary assessment of UCSA’s capacity is 
in Appendix 4 and a detailed assessment is in Supplementary Appendix C. 
 
11.  Lessons Learned. Experience from other externally assisted projects in Uzbekistan and 
ADB's  experience  in  similar  projects  indicates  that  the  main  problems  faced  during  the 
implementation  of  large-scale  rural  WSS  services  projects  relate  to  insufficient  community 
consultation and participation in the planning and design of subprojects. This contributes to 
nonfunctioning  or  nonestablishment  of  local  utility  agencies,  lack  of  guarantees  for  O&M 
financing, inadequate O&M, and weak cost recovery. The need to focus on sustainability of 
operations  has  been  recognized.  Further,  limited  government  experience  in  project 
implementation has led to delays and slow disbursement in some projects. Another lesson 
learned concerns the institutional capacity of oblast governments, which lack familiarity with 
ADB’s implementation procedures and require training and technical support. These issues 
were  reviewed  during  project  processing,  and  comprehensive  measures  have  been 
incorporated  in  the  project  design.  The  Government, ADB,  and  other  donor  agencies  are 
currently focusing on community consultation and decentralization of implementation. External 
assistance to the sector is in Appendix 5. 
 
12.  Policy Dialogue. A key rationale for ADB support for the sector is ADB’s policy dialogue 
with the Government and the fact that ADB support for WSS is provided in a policy context.

4 
Policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  in  the  WSS  sector  has  covered  capacity  building, 
decentralization,  ensuring  a  poverty  focus,  and  institutional  and  financial  sustainability. 
Supplementary  Appendix  D  provides  the  policy  framework  addressing  issues  and  actions 
required. The Government has agreed to rehabilitate and expand existing WSS infrastructure in 
poor  rural  areas  using  simple,  least-cost  solutions.  Policy  dialogue  has  also  covered 
development of local WSS services and the need for further rehabilitation and extension of long-
distance water supply transmission mains. Updating of national groundwater resources data is 
essential for the planned decentralization of small-scale water supply systems, which would 
enhance their economic viability. 
 
13.  From  the  institutional  point  of  view,  the  Project  is  designed  to  increase  local-level 
responsibilities for WSS infrastructure services by decentralizing implementation and O&M, and 
actively  involving  all  stakeholders.  Policy  dialogue  has  covered  local-level  O&M  of  WSS 
infrastructure facilities, and communities will be involved in O&M of the constructed facilities 
through  their  newly  created  Drinking  Water  Consumers  Unions  (DWCUs).  The  process  of 
decentralization of responsibilities in the WSS sector requires a corresponding strengthening of 
the  sector  institutions  at  central  level—but  particularly  at  oblast  level—to  provide  close 
monitoring of the performance of the new DWCUs and undertake correction measures for poor 
performers. 
 
14.  Sector  Lending  Approach.  The  Project  has  been  formulated  in  line  with  the 
Government’s  sector  policies,  strategy,  and  investment  plan.  The  Government  has  well 
formulated water sector policies, development objectives, and an approach to rural water supply 
infrastructure development, as well as a development plan for the WSS sector. UCSA, the EA, 
has significant experience in implementing similar projects supported by the World Bank and 
ADB, and has the capability to implement the sector investment plan. The Government has met 
the three requirements for sector lending: (i) a sector development plan, (ii) the institutional 
capacity to implement the plan, and (iii) appropriate sector policies.  
 
15.  ADB  has  reviewed  4  of  the  12  prospective  subprojects  to  confirm  the  approaches, 
methodology,  and  procedures  of  subproject  selection  and  appraisal—Kamashi  and  Kasan 
subprojects in Kashkadarya oblast, and Kyzyltepa and Nurota subprojects in Navoi oblast. 
Kamashi  and  Kasan  subprojects  are  supplied  with  groundwater  from  local  trunk  main 
Shakhrisbz-Karshi-Mubarak  developed  at  the  existing  wellfield  of  Shahkrizabs.  A  list  of 
subprojects is in Supplementary Appendix E. The Navoi subproject is fed from trunk main 
Damkhodj while the Nurota subproject is supplied with groundwater from production wells. The 
subprojects  are  viable  in  terms  of  technical,  institutional,  social,  financial,  economic,  and 
environmental aspects. The remaining 8 subprojects are being formulated in accordance with 
the agreed selection criteria and appraisal procedures (Supplementary Appendix F), which 
include:  (i)  preparation  of  a  feasibility  study;  and  (ii)  appraisal,  including  preparation  of  a 
subproject appraisal report.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
16.  The impact of the Project is to improve living conditions and public health in rural areas of 
Kashkadarya and Navoi oblasts. The outcome of the Project is improved access to WSS in the 
project areas. The Project will upgrade service levels and delivery efficiency, and achieve better 
cost recovery by providing capacity building and project management support. The Project will 
assist the Government in (i) implementing institutional reform for WSS infrastructure services;

5 
and (ii) providing and upgrading reliable and financially sustainable WSS services that will 
improve public health, promote economic development, and reduce rural poverty. The project 
area will cover Kashkadarya and Navoi oblasts, which have significant levels of poverty (38% in 
Kashkadarya and 24% in Navoi) and an identified demand for development of WSS services.  
 
B.  Outputs 
 
17.  The Project consists of two parts: Part A: Physical Infrastructure; and Part B: Institutional 
Development, which includes a capacity-building program, a hygiene and sanitation education 
(HSE) program, and consulting services for project management support. Summary feasibility 
studies and short descriptions of the four core subprojects are in Supplementary Appendix G. 
 
1.  Part A: Physical Infrastructure  
 
18.  Part A includes 12 subprojects, covering about 170 villages with populations ranging from 
300 to 8,000, a total of about 250,000. Each subproject will cover a cluster of up to 20 villages 
within one rayon and comprise an integrated water supply system, including improvement of 
sanitation  facilities.  The  subprojects  will  consist  of  the  development  or  rehabilitation  and 
upgrading  of  piped  water  supply  systems,  construction  of  public  and  school  latrines,  and 
participatory improvement of wastewater drainage facilities. The development and expansion of 
the water supply systems will include construction and/or rehabilitation of water source intakes, 
construction  of  pumping  stations,  treatment  facilities,  storage  reservoirs,  transmission  and 
distribution pipelines, and individual yard or house connections. The subprojects will derive 
supplies from different types of water sources. Most subprojects will use groundwater sources, 
and  will  require  development  and/or  rehabilitation  of  water  supply  systems  and  drilling  of 
production wells. The new development of water supply will be coordinated with wastewater 
drainage measures consisting of basic improvements to village drainage networks. Public and 
school toilets will be rehabilitated and, where feasible, connected to septic tanks.  
 
19.  The physical infrastructure component will cover around 10% of the approximately 1,700 
villages in the two project oblasts. About 1,200 villages (70%) do not have any formal piped 
water supply system, while the remaining 500 villages (30%) are supplied from trunk mains or 
local  sources.  About  11%  (250,000)  of  the  total  rural  population  in  the  project  oblasts 
(2.2 million) will be covered by the 12 subprojects. Of the 12 subprojects—each involving one 
rayon and an integrated water supply system covering up to 20 villages—7 systems will utilize 
groundwater sources distributed from trunk mains and 5 will be supplied from local groundwater 
sources. On average, the per capita investment cost is about $140.

areas without groundwater resources, which can be supplied by long-distance interregional or 
regional trunk mains; (ii) settlements that can be supplied from a locally developed water

supply is the desalination of locally available salinized groundwater. In selecting settlements for 
the subprojects, priority is given to settlements with no water supply or a nonworking water 
supply system, located near a reliable source of fresh water. In addition, the following criteria 
are  included  in  subproject  selection:  (i)  settlements  with  low-income  level,  (ii)  willingness

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Environmental Impacts and Benefits 
 
42.  Overall, the Project is environmentally beneficial. Initial environmental examinations (IEEs) 
were  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Environmental  Policy  (2002),  Environmental 
Assessment  Guidelines  (2003),  and  national  guidelines.6  A  summary  initial  environmental 
examination (SIEE) is in Appendix 10. The physical subprojects component—involving simple, 
appropriate,  low-cost  technology—does  not  pose  any  significant  adverse  environmental 
consequences. The provision of safe drinking water and proper sanitation facilities is expected 
to have a significant positive impact on improvement of the environment. Water resources, 
particularly groundwater, are scarce throughout the country. The use of centralized water supply 
from centralized water resources systems is usually the most cost-effective and economic 
solution.  When  available,  local  fresh  groundwater  resources  are  developed  to  feed 
decentralized waters supply systems, provided the water quality meets the required standards 
and the annual replenishment allows sustainable development. The quality of water resources 
selected for development has been reviewed and fit the norms. The Government’s environment 
sector policies and the capacity of the Government agencies involved are adequate. The IEE 
reports  and  the  SIEE  have  concluded  that  none  of  the  subprojects  are  environmentally 
sensitive.  Environmental  concerns,  for  which  appropriate  safeguards  will  be  built  into  the 
subproject  designs,  include:  (i)  protection  of  environmentally  sensitive  areas  around  water 
sources, (ii) provision for proper collection and disposal of wastewater, (iii) controlled long-term 
extraction from groundwater sources, (iv) safeguarding the interests of downstream users of 
surface  sources,  (v)  protection  measures  for  historical  monuments  and  natural  sites  of 
ecological importance, and (vi) avoiding encroachment on household perimeters and cultivated 
lands. The core subprojects’ IEEs are in Supplementary Appendix M and the environmental 
assessment and review framework (EARF) is in Supplementary Appendix N.

43.  A poverty and social analysis was undertaken for the Project as a whole—covering the 
12 subprojects—to  assess  the  demand,  need,  capacity,  WTP  and  affordability,  gender, 
community participation, and other risks. Although it is a sector project, no poverty and social 
assessment is required for additional subprojects. The Project will benefit about 250,000 people,

C.  Institutional Benefits  
 
1.  Project Benefits and Impacts 
 
49.  The Project will benefit about 250,000 people, of which more than 30% are considered 
poor, in the two project oblasts through provision of improved access to safe and reliable water 
supply and better sanitation facilities. Technical, economic, and financial analyses confirm that 
the least-cost, long-term solutions involve development and/or rehabilitation of water sources 
and water supply systems. This approach will bring social and economic benefits, including 
poverty  reduction,  financial  sustainability  at  affordable  levels  for  project  beneficiaries,  and 
positive environmental impacts. Institutional solutions and community participation in the design 
and implementation of the subprojects will enhance the efficiency and sustainability of the sector 
program and subprojects.  
 
2.  Institutional Strengthening 
 
50.  The UCSA is currently implementing another ADB-assisted water supply project, and has 
adequate capacity and experience to implement the Project. However, there is a need for 
institutional  strengthening  at  local  government  levels,  especially:  (i)  planning  and  financial 
management systems; and (ii) community participation structures and processes, and capability 
to handle resettlement issues, including the design and implementation of resettlement plans. 
Institutional  strengthening  is  directly  incorporated  in  the  Project  through  the  institutional 
development component, including a capacity-building program, HSE program, and consulting 
services for project management support. 
 
D.  Economic and Financial Aspects 
 
1.  Economic Aspects 
 
51.  The economic analysis covers both the Project as a whole, and the individual subprojects 
(Appendix 13). For the Project as a whole, the analysis covers the economic rationale for 
government  intervention,  and  the  goals  and  general  design  of  the  investment  plan.  The 
economic rationale is sound, based on social responsibility to provide basic social services and 
controlling natural monopoly (water supply). The goals of the investment plan are to meet 
targets for rural water supply development and control of the spread of waterborne disease, 
especially  in  hard-to-reach  areas.  The  targets  are  clearly  defined,  legally  established,  and 
consistent with government goals for sustainable development in rural water supply, as defined 
in the National Water Supply Development Program (NWSDP), 2000–2010. The plan to meet 
targets is based on centralized water supply systems designed using least-cost solutions based 
on  type  and  availability  of  water  resources  and  variations  in  scope,  design  technologies, 
location,  and  planning  horizon.  Other  project  goals  consistent  with  NWSDP  include  cost 
recovery and sustainability tariffs, conservation and economic use of water, and improved 
decentralization.  Economic  cost-benefit  analysis  for  the  individual  subprojects  was  also

16 
undertaken to strengthen the economic justification. The economic internal rate of return for the 
four representative subprojects range between 23% and 36%. 
 
2.  Financial Aspects 
 
52.  Financial evaluation of the four representative core subprojects was undertaken in real 
terms using constant April 2005 prices. The project cost estimates and financial projections in 
nominal terms after tax were converted to real terms by adjusting for foreign and domestic 
inflation and currency fluctuation. The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) for each subproject 
is  more  than  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital,  computed  on  an  after-tax  basis.  The 
subprojects are considered both financially viable and sustainable. The FIRRs for the four core 
subprojects range between 6.6% and 7.9%, averaging 7.2%. This compares favorably with the 
weighted average cost of capital of 4.5%. Sensitivity and risk analyses indicate that the FIRR is 
robust under adverse conditions. Projected tariffs are within the accepted limit, so they are 
affordable to low-income group households. 
 
53.  Financial projections were prepared for each of the subproject entities in accordance with 
ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the  Financial  Governance  and  Management  of  Investment  Projects 
Financed by ADB (2002) and ADB’s Framework for the Economic and Financial Appraisal of 
Urban Development Sector Projects (1994) to assess the financial viability and sustainability of 
each subproject (Appendix 14). Projected financial statements indicate that financial revenues 
will be sufficient to cover O&M costs from the first year of operation and a substantial portion of 
depreciation  from  years  1–4.  By  year  5,  the subprojects  will  have achieved  financial self-
sufficiency to attain full cost recovery during the remaining repayment period. Details of the 
financial analysis for the four core subprojects are presented in Supplementary Appendix S. 
 
3.  Affordability Analysis and Project Sustainability 
 
54.  The water supply subprojects will be community driven from the initial stage of formulation 
and  construction,  and  DWCUs  will  participate  in  O&M  of  the  schemes  as  self-supporting 
agencies to the extent possible. Based on the survey undertaken, the rural population appears 
willing to increase water services payments. Expressed as a percentage of average household 
income of the low-income group, the tariffs are expected to vary between 2.3% and 5.7% for 
low-income households in Kashkadarya (4.0% average), and between 1.9% and 7.5% in Navoi 
(4.7% average). These values are within the accepted standards from 3% to 5%. Since it is 
likely that poorer households will collect water from public standpipes at a fixed monthly rate, 
the cost will be much less than for households with in-house connections. The subproject 
revenues are expected to cover O&M costs and depreciation to ensure project sustainability.  
 
E.  Project Risks 
 
55.  Three  possible  risks  have  been  identified.  First,  the  possibility  of  delays  in  project 
implementation caused by weak institutional capability to implement, operate, and maintain 
water supply systems has been addressed through clear delineation of agency responsibilities 
and inclusion of coordination mechanisms. Considerable preparatory work has been undertaken 
in the potential subproject communities regarding the present status of water supply facilities, 
and an initial assessment of required development has been carried out. Substantial support will 
also  be  provided  for  capacity  building  through  training  programs  and  consulting  services. 
Second, the potential for delays in project implementation caused by lack of local counterpart 
funds has been addressed by the active participation of local administrations, which meet some 
construction supervision and all land requirements. Measures to reduce possible delays have

17 
been discussed with the Government. Third, limited financial capability to meet the incremental 
O&M of the expanded water supply systems has been dealt with by including the institutional 
development program, which should strengthen the capacity to undertake the O&M of the 
expanded water supply systems. The Project will be closely monitored, with two reviews a year 
throughout implementation.

  SUMMARY OF WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION SECTOR POLICY 
 
A.  The Basis of the Policy 
 
1.  Uzbekistan’s water supply and sanitation policy (the Policy), particularly as it relates to 
the rural sector, is underpinned by three legal instruments: (i) the national 10-year water supply 
development scheme approved by the Cabinet of Ministers in 1999, (ii) the resolution of the 
Cabinet of Ministers approved in 2003 (RCM No. 405), and (iii) the latest annual investment 
program approved by the Cabinet of Ministers. 
 
2.  The Government of Uzbekistan places a high priority on the sustainable development of 
rural settlements as a precondition for fostering countrywide development. The Government 
prefers an integrated rural development policy, which targets the overall sustainability of rural 
settlements and sets the following main objectives: (i) improvement of environmental conditions, 
(ii) improvement of rural incomes, (iii) provision of adequate housing, (iv) availability of social 
and health services, and (v) coverage of people’s needs in drinking water and sanitation.  
 
3.  Uzbekistan  is  a  signatory  to  Agenda  21.  As  such,  it  has  adopted  the  principle  of 
“rationalization  of  utilization  of  land,  water  and  other  natural  resources  to  conserve  their 
reserves for forthcoming generations” as one of its major goals for sustainable development. 
Further, recognizing the significant disparities in the levels of development between urban 
centers  and  rural  villages,  the  Government’s  support  for  the  transition  to  sustainable 
development prioritizes: (i) the needs of rural settlements, (ii) redressing regional disparities, 
and (iii) addressing the needs of the poorer segment of the population based on the overall 
principle  that  sustainable  development  of  rural  settlements  determines  the  sustainability  of 
countrywide development.  
 
4.  The Policy emphasizes the adoption of cost-effective construction technologies and 
improvement  of  management  procedures  oriented  towards  economic  use  of  water  and 
reduction of water wastage through: (i) installation of water meters; (ii) elimination of leakages, 
illegal connections, and other water losses; (iii) further reduction of specific rates of water 
demand; and (iv) improvement of water tariff collection performance.  
 
5.  The Government has prepared and started a number of national programs targeted at 
contributing to sustainable overall development of rural settlements, funded by the national 
budget, as well as loans and grants from external sources. In the rural sanitation subsector, the 
focus of government efforts has been on upgrading basic sanitation services and fostering 
school sanitation and hygiene through a series of integrated projects. Nine interregional water 
supply systems are targeted for completion by 2010. These constitute the least-cost solution for 
the supply of large areas, in comparison with the main alternative, which is desalination.

A.  Medium- to Long-Term Development Strategy 
 
1.  The main goals of Uzbekistan’s medium- to long-term economic policy are to ensure 
steady, long-term growth as the basis of improving living standards. Core objectives targeted by 
the  Government’s  development  strategy  for  the  medium-term  development  plan  until  2010 
include: (i) undertaking social measures aimed at reducing the poverty level, (ii) creating new 
job opportunities, and (iii) increasing household income.  
 
2.  A  number  of  major  programs  have  been  completed  or  are  currently  under 
implementation, including the state housing support program, health reform program, national 
personnel training program, water supply and sanitation program, natural gas supply program, 
state  family  protection  program,  and  other  programs.  In  the  public  utilities  sector,  the 
Government has recognized the most acute social problem as the lack of adequate supply of 
safe water, particularly in rural areas. This situation is exacerbated by the ecological problems 
of the Aral Sea, and the pollution and depletion of surface and groundwater resources.  
 
3.  Since  1991,  the  Government  has  pursued  expansion  of  Uzbekistan’s  piped  water 
supply.  In  implementing  its  water  supply  program,  the  Government  has  placed  particular 
emphasis on the development of long distance, interregional transmission mains, carrying water 
from its source to urban and rural settlements where no fresh water is available.  
 
4.  The  Government  establishes  3-year  Public  Investment  Programs  (PIPs)  aimed  at 
implementing its strategies and objectives. In developing each PIP, all ministries are involved in 
the programming process and determination of priorities. A PIP is refined on an annual basis 
with an investment program and promulgated as a Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers (RCM) 
as an annual investment program. The investment program for 2005 was adopted by RCM No. 
560 of 30 November 2004. 
 
B.  Water Supply Development Program  
 
5.  Through  the  National  Water  Supply  Development  Program  (NWSDP)  2000–10 
(the Program), the Government envisages: (i) construction of water supply systems and raising 
the level of drinking water supply to benefit 85% of the rural population by 2010, increasing to 
100% by 2020; and (ii) provision of remote and hard-to-reach areas with alternative water 
supply sources. The NWSDP also gives particular emphasis to the adoption of new construction 
technologies,  demand  management  directed  towards  economic  use  of  water  and  wastage 
reduction, and enhancement of private participation and decentralization initiatives. 
 
6.  The NWSDS proposes staged development of Uzbekistan’s water supply infrastructure 
by 2010. Based on the Program and recognizing the urgency to achieve of the goals, the 
Government has set up and started a number of projects targeted at contributing to the overall 
sustainable development of rural settlements, using the national budget and loans and grants 
from external sources.

supply sector at $896 million until 2005, and an additional $1,527 million from 2006 to 2010. For 
rehabilitation of the rural water supply sector, the needs were estimated at $930 million (until

A.  The Project’s Physical Components 
 
1.  The main physical components of the Project will include the construction of: (i) 200 km 
of transmission pipelines up to 250 mm in diameter; (ii) about 850 km of distribution pipelines, 
50–100 mm in diameter; (iii) 33 new pumping stations, including reservoirs and chlorination 
facilities; and (iv) about 43 new production wells, including pumping and disinfection facilities. 
The water supply works will also include the rehabilitation of some existing production wells and 
pumping stations. In addition, the Project will rehabilitate about 170 toilet facilities in schools. 
 
B.  Existing Environment  
 
1.  Physical Environment 
 
2.  The Kashkadarya River originated in western Tajikistan, enters the Kashkadarya oblast 
at the northeastern boundaries of the oblast, and ends its course in a desert area in the 
northwestern  part  of  the  oblast.  The  Zarafshan  River,  also  originating  in  Tajikistan,  flows 
westerly, across the southern part of the Navoi oblast. The Aydarkul salty lake, occupying a 
natural depression in the northern part of the Nurota rayon, is the largest water body entirely 
within the territory of Uzbekistan. In a large part of the two project oblast territories, especially 
Navoi oblast, groundwater is salinized with total dissolved solids content often exceeding 5 g/l. 
However, there are aquifers with variable amounts of freshwater reserves in some of the project 
rayons in Kashkadarya and Navoi oblasts. The most important groundwater resources are in the 
alluvial deposits of the Kashkadarya river and its tributaries, in the territory of the Kitab and 
Shahrizabs rayons, in the northeast of Kashkadarya oblast. The quality of the groundwater is 
generally good. 
 
2.  Socioeconomic Environment 
 
3.  The average household size in rural areas is 6.7 in Kashkadarya and 6.2 in Navoi, with 
2.1 (Kashkadarya) and 2.5 (Navoi) persons in each household in permanent or temporary 
employment (including children under 15 years old). The employment rate of employable-age 
population  is  about  70%  in  Kashkadarya  and  73%  in  Navoi  oblasts,  which  is  quite  high 
compared with the national average. Only 31% of rural households in Kashkadarya  and 32% in 
Navoi have access to piped drinking water, mostly through a street standpipe. However, water 
is distributed for an average of 1 to 3 hours a day in most villages with piped water service, and 
the service is often interrupted for several consecutive days. In some settlements, piped water is 
available only once a week. Better-off households buy relatively expensive water from water 
vendors. A large part of the rural population living in project areas uses alternative, unsafe water 
(including rainwater) from rivers and irrigation canals. Consequently, at least one person in 10% 
of rural householders in Kashkadarya in 16% in Navoi oblast contracted waterborne diseases in 
2004. Parasitic and communicable gastrointestinal diseases are the most frequent, followed by 
non-communicable gastrointestinal disease, kidney disease, and skin disease. About 14% of 
rural households in Kashkadarya and 35% in Navoi oblast have a room designated for bathing 
in their housing, but water is transported to these rooms by buckets. Non-ventilated pit latrines 
in domestic gardens are used to dispose of human waste. Most of these toilets in the surveyed 
households are not equipped with leak-proof concrete lining. In general, schools in the project 
villages do not have water supply or have a non-functioning supply, and are equipped with non-
ventilated pit latrines comprising 4 to 12 holes.

C.  Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
 
1.  Environmental Impacts Caused by the Project Location 
 
6.  The territory of all project areas includes generally agricultural or nonclassified land. 
Permanent infrastructure will require the permanent restriction from any use of about 45 ha of 
mainly agricultural land. The location of infrastructure to be constructed can be designed with 
flexibility, taking care to the extent possible to locate permanent, on-ground infrastructures (such 
as pumping stations, production wells, and elevated tanks) in areas that would not cause 
significant environmental implications. Losses resulting from temporary and permanent use of 
land will be compensated in the frame of a resettlement plan. Raw sources of water (including 
surface and groundwater), which will be selected as the sources for water supply in each 
subproject, will have to be tested before the final decision for development. The results of the 
quality tests must prove that the water is suitable for drinking. Before undertaking long-term 
exploitation  of  groundwater,  accurate  assessment  of  the  annual  average  replenishment  of 
groundwater reservoir will be conducted. The long-term design yield of each production well 
added up to the yield of other wells already in use will not exceed the aquifer’s sustainable 
annual recharge.  
 
2.  Impacts Related to Design 
 
7.  Alternative design options can be developed to optimize the location of the production 
well sites, pumping stations, and elevated pressure reservoirs which will require permanent 
occupation of land. Pipeline construction will cause temporary occupation of land along rights of 
way. Measures are taken to design and construct transmission mains and distribution networks 
in areas implying no or minor environmental concerns. Transmission mains will be designed 
along existing roads, to the extent possible. Measures are also being taken to avoid any 
encroachment on natural protected sites of historical and archaeological importance, if any, 
during construction works.

3.  Impacts during Construction and Mitigation Measures 
 
8.  Occupation of Agricultural Land. Measures will be taken at the design stage to avoid

to be enforced by contractors in accordance with the national code for traffic safety. Temporary 
or permanent traffic lights will be installed by contractors in most sensible road crossings, under 
the supervision of the project implementation unit (PIU). Traffic police control will be intensified 
in villages during construction and adequate warning will be provided to enhance vigilance 
among schoolchildren. 
 
10.  Air Pollution. Temporary environmental concerns related to the use of excavators, 
cranes, compressors, and other machinery during construction works will include: (i) noise and 
dust from construction sites, and (ii) safety for workers and inhabitants. Measures will include: 
(i) avoiding  work  with  noisy  equipment  in  settled  areas  at  night;  (ii)  careful  conduction  of 
excavation, earthmoving works, and transportation of earth, particularly within settled areas; and 
(iii) use of masks by operators. 
 
11.  Water Resources. Some main natural watercourses cross subproject areas, and in 
some cases, irrigation canals. Protection zones are normally established along the main natural 
watercourses. All necessary measures shall be taken to respect the restriction rules within the 
measures. Some local groundwater aquifers constitute significant alternative resources for local 
water supplies in certain subproject areas. Adequate waste management measures will be 
implemented to prevent accidental pollution of water resources. 
 
12.  Soils. Soils could be exposed to contamination by the same sources of pollution as 
water resources (para. 11). Soil protection measures are to be enforced in accordance with the 
RU norms КМК 3.01.01-97 and КМК 3.05.03-97. During pipeline construction, organic topsoil

removed earth. The organic soil will be placed on top of the backfilling material, compacted, and 
restored to agricultural use.

specially allocated disposal and reclamation sites. After completion of construction works, all job 
sites will be cleaned and landscaped. Sanitation facilities will be constructed at the work sites. 
 
14.  Historical and Cultural Sites and Landscape. The subproject areas are located away 
from historical monuments. Before starting works, an inventory of all historical monuments and 
cultural heritage sites will be established with local rayon authorities and oblast departments of 
the State Committee for Nature Protection. Any discovery of archaeological remnants during 
excavation works will be reported immediately to the rayon authorities.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The  economic  analysis  covers  the  Project  as  a  whole,  as  well  as  the  individual 
subprojects.  For  the  overall  Project,  the  analysis  covers  the:  (i)  rationale  for  government 
intervention, (ii) goals of the investment plan, (iii) general design of the investment plan, and 
(iv) strategy to attain the plan. The economic analysis also evaluates the individual subprojects 
relative to the selection criteria, focusing on least-cost analysis undertaken. 
 
B.  Analysis of the Project 
 
1.  Rationale for Public Intervention 
 
2.  The  rationale  for  government  intervention  results  from  increasing  concern  over  the 
worsening  water  supply  situation  in  the  rural  settlements,  defined  by  low  and  declining 
coverage, made worse by the slow pace of development in the sector. Despite government 
efforts at social construction in rural settlements, access to water supply—especially for remote 
and hard-to-reach areas—is still rudimentary. This has also led to negative impacts on the 
health of the poor, which recent studies confirm are the most affected. 
 
3.  Although 70% of the total rural settlements are currently within reach of centralized water 
supply, only about 30–40% of the rural population still has real access to partially functioning 
piped water supply systems nationwide. The reason is that most of these supply systems are in 
various stages of deterioration and some are dysfunctional. As a result, residents are forced to 
use alternative, unsafe sources of water from rivers or canals. Recognition by the Government 
of  the  seriousness  of  the  problem  led  to  reforms  being  undertaken  in  the  sector.  Recent 
regulations have been passed to promote decentralization in the provision of these services. In 
the  case  of  rural  water  supply,  the  responsibility  for  and  ownership  of  assets  have  been 
conferred on the oblast or provincial administration, with operation and maintenance handled by 
the oblast vodokanal through the rayon or district vodokanal under its stewardship. By detail, 
water supply services in rural settlements are under the rayon vodokanal. However, studies 
show that where such centralized systems exist, services only continue to deteriorate because 
little  could  be  done  in  improving  and  rehabilitating  the  systems  due  to  lack  of  funds. 
Unrealistically low tariffs with a poor basis or no basis of determination result in very limited 
revenue generation. Additionally, rayon vodokanals depend on subsidies from the oblast budget 
to cover financial needs for large-scale system repair or extension works. Consequently, under 
the  present  institutional  context,  rayon  vodokanals  are  neither  institutionally  nor  financially 
independent water utilities. Water supply is rationed only a few hours a day and schedules are 
often not met. Many rayon vodokanals on which rural water supply depends are characterized 
by inefficient operations, poor service levels, poor state of repair, weak institutional capacity, 
scarcity of water resources, and financial inadequacy. In the past, agro-vodokanals managed 
rural systems, as most are situated along agricultural areas encompassing rural settlements. 
Some agro-vodokanals still exist but are now being gradually phased out by virtue of a law that 
declares their abolition. Another entity, the Obi Hayot, continues to be a service provider in rural 
settlements, but its interests lie in managing systems that guarantee profits, and there are 
probably no networks of the scale targeted in the proposed sector investment plan, which could 
offer the same incentive in the near term. 
 
4.  Government involvement in the investment plan is justified because there is significant 
scope  to  improve  water  supply  in  rural  settlements  through  the  provision  of  financial  and 
technical support and institutional strengthening, which only the Government can effectively

provide at present. Despite steps taken to improve physical facilities through social construction, 
the actual flow of benefits from such undertakings is minimally felt by target beneficiaries. The 
institutional and economic reforms embedded in the decentralization efforts have progressed 
very slowly within the sector, as with the others, as the country continues to assimilate a market 
economy. The Government transferred the responsibility and ownership of existing assets to 
vodokanals through recent regulations, and private sector participation is opening up. However, 
there is a defined need for central level management to sufficiently develop and address the

These entities now require further economic support and regulation to persevere to the intended

empowerment of village communities through direct participation in planning and management

5.  The economic rationale is likewise sound because addressing the rural water supply 
problems  closes  the  existing  disparities  in  service  provision  between  urban  and  rural 
communities, promotes economic growth in the rural settlements, and supports government 
mandated functions related to regulating the monopolistic characteristics of water trunk main 
supply and distribution and provision of public goods.

independence, the emphasis of water supply investments was on construction of long-distance 
trunk and secondary distribution mains that focused mostly on more feasible urban areas. 
Currently,  the  strategy  has  shifted  to  include  unserved  rural  settlements  when  pursuing 
rehabilitation and new construction of transmission and distribution networks, while ensuring the

water  resources,  including  desalination.  Under  the  National  Water  Supply  Development

sector,  including  remote  and  hard-to-reach  areas,  total  requirements  are  estimated  at

tariff and cost recovery systems and the adoption of water metering programs; (ii) planning

domestic  and  external  sources;  (iii)  achieving  further  decentralization  of  water  supply  and 
sanitation services through the institutional and financial strengthening of oblast administrations 
and vodokanals, and the establishment of Drinking Water Consumer Unions (DWCUs) at rural 
community level; (iv) encouraging private sector participation through competitive procurement 
procedures and private investments in water supply and sanitation (WSS) related goods and 
services; and (v) supporting public-private partnerships in the ownership and operation of WSS 
utilities. The Government envisions that improved general welfare of the rural population, mostly 
consisting of agricultural and industrial workers in the project regions, will lessen poverty and 
increase productivity. Increased productivity will lead to higher incomes for workers in these

2.  Goals of the Project 
9.  The goals of the Project are consistent with government economic policy, which ensures 
sustainable growth by: (i) improving the living conditions of the population through focused 
social infrastructure development, and (ii) closing the disparity between urbanized towns and 
rural villages. Major programs have been undertaken, or are currently ongoing in the public 
utilities sector, in which the Government has recognized the acute inadequacy of water supply 
in rural areas. Until 1999, the Government mostly directed investments towards long-distance 
transmission mains and externally-financed water supply projects through central development 
planning mechanisms like the Public Investment Program (PIP), while local urban and rural 
water supply investments were borne by oblast administrations. Since then, the Government 
has  included  specific  targets  in  its  focus  for  the  development  of  water  supply  in  rural 
settlements, and sourcing of internal and external investments to economically support these 
plans, through implementation guidelines in successive cabinet regulations. Guided by the 
NWSDP for the period 2000–10, the Government envisaged: (i) construction of water supply 
systems and raising the level of drinking water supply to benefit 85% of the rural population by 
2010, increasing to 100% by 2020; and (ii) the provision of remote and hard-to-reach areas with 
alternative water supply sources. The NWSDP also gives particular emphasis to: (i) adoption of 
least-cost technologies, (ii) demand management directed towards economic use of water and 
reduction of wastage, (iii) financial sustainability through gradual cost recovery of infrastructure 
capital and targeted subsidies, and (iv) further decentralization of sector services. 
10.  The goals set out in the development of the proposed Project are directly relevant to the 
investment plan and in line with the plan’s goals. By 2010, the Project aims to provide water 
supply to about 250,000 inhabitants in 170 rural settlements, some of which are situated in 
remote and hard-to-reach areas. The rural settlements of Kashkadarya and Navoi have been 
identified in the NWSDP as among those areas in the country with the lowest water supply 
service coverage. Most of the rural settlements targeted in the Project have had no experience 
with piped water supply service at all. Scarcity of water resources in many of these settlements 
has been given high significance in project planning. Alternative water sources have been 
assessed as part of least cost planning.

unaccounted-for-water,  (viii)  length  of  transmission  mains  (km),  (ix)  length  of  distribution 
pipelines  (km),  (x)  percentage  of  population  coverage,  (xi)  cost  of  planned  development 
scheme, (xii) per capita cost of development or improvement, (xiii) per capita consumption 
(liters/day), and (xiv) total number of in-yard connections. 
14.  To  further  give  direction  to  the  implementation  of  the  schemes,  adherence  to  the 
following guidelines is also monitored: (i) organization in the supply and consumption of water; 
(ii) systematic activities on identification and reduction of water leakages in distribution networks 
and in-house systems; (iii) replacement of deteriorated pipelines; (iv) implementation of efficient 
water  tariff  policy,  which  ensures  self-sufficient  operations  and  possibility  for  expansion; 
(v) measures taken to protect poor consumers; (vi) monitoring of usage of potable water supply 
for purposes other than drinking, e.g., watering of crops, substitute for irrigation, etc.; (vii) use of 
water saving technologies in operations; and (viii) type and frequency of water quality testing.  
3.  Design of the Plan 
 
15.  The goals of the plan will be achieved at least cost through centralized water supply 
systems developed from least-cost alternatives. A structured approach will be adopted for the 
appraisal and approval of subprojects included in the plan. Subprojects will be selected based 
on availability and the type of water resources, and must also be among the number of villages 
that  are  in  most  urgent  need  of  water  supply.  For  Kashkadarya  and  Navoi,  the  oblast 
administrations must also submit a request providing evidence that the basic conditions for 
inclusion of subprojects are fulfilled. These include: (i) willingness of the settlers to establish and 
constitute a DWCU and select a board from among union members; (ii) willingness to set, apply, 
and pay water tariffs for water consumed; and (iii) commitment of the local administrations to 
implement a resettlement plan for settlers that may be affected by the constructed facilities. A 
social survey conducted in the two oblasts reports a relatively high demand for the proposed 
service.  The  willingness  of  beneficiaries  to  pay  for  centralized  water  supply  is  84%  in 
Kashkadarya and 74% in Navoi. 
 
16.  The composition of subprojects is determined foremost by water resource type and 
availability.  In  areas  without  groundwater  resources,  contiguous  or  close-to-contiguous 
settlements at a reasonable distance from an existing trunk main may constitute a subproject.

Appendix 13       53      
Where groundwater is available, a subproject may include a cluster of settlements served by 
individual  production  wells.  A  single  well  source  may  serve  one  or  several  villages.  Each 
subproject may comprise 10 to 20 villages, all within the political boundaries of a single rayon. 
Each centralized water supply system will be designed at least cost, in terms of location, 
planning horizon, and design. The investments will be prioritized, since the size and scope of 
the  plan  prevent  all  investments  from  being  made  simultaneously.  Availability  of  local 
contractors,  timely  release  of  counterpart  funds,  and  capacity  of  project  management  and 
design institutes will be considered. 
 
17.  Uzbekistan’s freshwater resources are limited and localized, particularly groundwater, 
which  commonly  allows  the  development  of  the  most  economic  water  supply  systems 
alternatives  for  small  and  decentralized  systems.  The  scarcity  of  the  resource  also  limits 
alternative solutions for water supply, particularly for small centers. Surface water of quality 
suitable for development is rare and can only be developed economically for large-scale water 
supplies.  In  implementing  the  plan  on  a  large  scale,  the  Government  has  prioritized  and 
invested efforts in the construction and rehabilitation of long-distance, interregional, or regional 
water supply transmission systems, fed from centralized, proven sustainable, water resources, 
as  the  least-cost  choice.  This  is  in  comparison  with  the  next  most  expensive  and 
environmentally unfriendly solution: desalination of locally available groundwater, as a strategic 
plan  to  meet  the  goal  of  covering  most  of  the  country’s  population  with  water  supply  at 
affordable costs. 
 
18.  For supply of rural settlements with drinking water, the main option is the development of 
local groundwater resources, when available, as the most economic solution for water supply. 
This is true particularly when several settlements can be fed from one single production well. In 
arid areas and areas without freshwater resources, the least-cost solution for the supply of small 
agglomerations  remains  the  supply  from  the  trunk  mains,  provided  the  distance  of  the 
settlement from the trunk main is affordable in terms of pipeline investments. The least-cost 
solution in this case consists of having a maximum number of neighboring villages supplied 
from a single pumping station, a model similar to that adopted for systems supplied from 
groundwater  wells.  Similar  types  of  models  have  been  developed  and  applied  in  defining 
subprojects and selecting least-cost improvement schemes under the technical assistance for 
the proposed Project. 
 
19.  Under the KNRWSSP, 12 subprojects have been selected following the screening and 
selection process given in Supplementary Appendix F and summarily discussed above. The 
criteria used in the selection process followed discussions and consultations between the oblast 
administration and vodokanal representatives, rural community leaders representing future and 
potential  beneficiaries,  representatives  of  the  Executing  Agency  (EA),  and  design  institute 
consultants. The 12 subproject areas and corresponding supply source options are as follows:

20.  One  of  the  procedural  requirements  for  subproject  selection  and  appraisal  is  the 
development of feasibility studies, which include both financial and economic analysis, for each 
subproject under consideration. Inclusion of the subproject in the list would require subproject 
investment to be financially and economically viable. Viability will be assessed based on the 
standard  financial  and  economic  cost-benefit  analysis.  Financial  viability  would  require  the 
financial internal rate of return (FIRR) to be higher than the cost of capital, and that benefits are 
based on tariffs affordable to consumers. Economic viability would be measured in terms of the 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR), which should be greater than the opportunity cost of 
capital. In instances where economic benefits are not quantifiable, economic analysis will be 
supplemented  with  socioeconomic  evaluation  that  would  aid  the  assessment.  A  critical 
sensitivity analysis will complete the cost-benefit analyses and the socioeconomic evaluation 
considering the impacts of alternative assumptions, risks, and imponderables.  
 
C.  Analysis of the Individual Subproject 
 
1.  Least-Cost Analysis of Individual Subprojects 
 
21.  Each subproject included in the list is designed to meet the goals of the Project at least 
cost. The least-cost analysis includes all feasible options for a given subproject, and considered 
variations in location, planning horizon, and design. 
22.  A  minimum  of  two  and  a  maximum  of  four  alternatives  were  assessed  for  each 
subproject based on the feasibility study options. The supply alternatives considered are as 
follows: (i) distribution network supplied by interregional transmission mains, (ii) freshwater from 
groundwater wells, (iii) desalinized water from groundwater wells, and (iv) surface water from 
river or canal. 
2.  General Assessment of Individual Subprojects 
23.  Aside  from  being  least-cost,  subprojects  must  be  economically  justified.  Standard 
benefit-cost  analysis  has  been  undertaken  to  strengthen  the  economic  justification  of 
subprojects. The benefit-cost analysis followed standard Asian Development Bank guidelines. 
The EIRRs have been derived for the individual subprojects. The EIRR for the representative 
subprojects range from 23% to 36% in Kashkadarya, and averages 26% for those in Navoi. 
Sensitivity tests indicate that the results are robust in all parameters. The proposed investments 
are therefore economically justified.

  FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.   Introduction 
 
1.  Financial analysis was prepared in accordance with the Guidelines for the Financial 
Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by the ADB and the Framework 
for the Economic and Financial Appraisal of Urban Development Sector Projects. The analysis 
determines  the  level  of  cost  recovery  from  users  required  to  cover  all  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) expenses and, eventually, capital to achieve financial sustainability. The 
analysis was carried out for four representative core water supply subprojects. 
 
B.  Financial Projections 
 
2.  Projections are based on information in the final feasibility study reports. Projections 
using  pro  forma  financial  statements  are  in  nominal  terms  and  are  shown  until  2020. 
Calculations of the financial internal rate of return (FIRR), extending to 2030, are in real terms 
and include a residual value that incorporates replacements. 
 
1.  System Operation and Maintenance 
 
3.  The  projections  are  prepared  on  increment  basis,  on  the  assumption  that  each 
subproject will be operated by Drinking Water Consumers Unions (DWCUs) at community level, 
and that DWCUs are yet to be organized and trained on system O&M at project implementation. 
At this point, DWCUs are assumed to operate as service utility organizations responsible to 
provide water supply service at village level, undertake minor system maintenance, set and 
collect tariffs, and issue directives on improvement of service delivery. Institutionally, DWCUs 
will be under the umbrella of the oblast vodokanal (water supply and sanitation agency), which 
encompass DWCU service areas, in terms of providing technical training, engineering support, 
and institutional advice. The institutional development component of the Project will ensure that 
DWCUs gain the status of certified utility organizations. During the early years of operation, 
when  DWCUs  will  not  have  attained  financial  self-sufficiency,  the  umbrella  vodokanal, 
supported  by  oblast  administration,  will  provide  an  operational  subsidy  to  cover  all  cash 
requirements,  including  partial  depreciation.  Projected  tariffs  are  set  so  that  oblast 
administration/oblast vodokanal may recover such subsidies when DWCUs finally attain self-
sufficient levels. 
 
2.  Cost and Financing Assumptions 
 
4.  The investment cost consists of all civil works and equipment, other development costs 
(engineering studies and supervision), and taxes and duties. O&M costs include expenses for 
personnel salaries, power and fuel, and plant and equipment maintenance. Annual domestic 
inflation is assumed at 7% throughout the projection period. Depreciation is assumed at 2% for 
civil  works  and  5%  for  mechanical  and  electrical  equipment.  Capital  outlays  during  post-
construction are budgeted to replace fully depreciated assets during the operational stage. 
Asset replacements are to be financed out of net operating income. 
 
5.  The investment will be financed through an ADB loan and equity contribution from the 
oblast administration. Terms of the ADB loan to the Government of Uzbekistan include a 32-
year loan period with an 8-year grace period, and interest of 1% during the grace period and 
1.5% thereafter. The arrangement will be that the ADB loan proceeds will be relent by the 
Government to the Uzbekistan Communal Services Agency (UCSA) at the same terms and 
conditions  as  the  original  loan  agreement.  UCSA  will  on-lend  the  funds  to  oblast 
administrations/oblast vodokanals on the same terms and conditions. Loan repayment will be 
the responsibility of the oblast administrations/oblast vodokanals from tariff collections at DWCU 
level.

3.  Tariffs, Cost Recovery, and Viability Parameters 
 
6.  Subproject tariffs are calculated based on the following cost recovery principles: (i) all 
O&M cost recovery from the start of operation, and (ii) all O&M cost from start of operation and 
partial recovery of depreciation during the initial years, graduating into full cost recovery in 
succeeding years as affordability levels permit. 
 
7.  Tariffs are likewise calculated so that they remain within the affordability of low-income 
households, set at about 5% of average household income. At the projected tariff levels, the 
subproject is deemed viable when the FIRR is higher than the weighted average cost of capital 
(WACC). Additionally, debt-coverage ratios are computed to determine subproject capacity to 
repay the loan, thus “freeing” oblast administration/oblast vodokanal from this obligation. With 
excess cash available after covering all other cash requirements, oblast administrations/oblast 
vodokanals may recover the amount earlier extended to DWCUs as operational subsidy. As 
affordability of tariffs is a critical issue during the initial years of subproject operation, the 
Government will commit to subsidize part of depreciation until DWCUs gain the capacity to 
cover depreciation. 
 
C.  Financial Evaluation 
 
1.  Proposed Tariffs
